Valorization of lignin in native corn stover via fractionation-hydrogenolysis process over cobalt-supported catalyst without external hydrogen Changcheng Shen Conceptualization Methodology Validation Formal analysis Investigation Data curation Writing – original draft a Wenzhi Li Formal analysis Resources Writing – review & editing Visualization Project administration Funding acquisition Supervision a b ⁎ Baikai Zhang Writing – review & editing a Fengyang Xue Writing – review & editing a Xiaomeng Dou Writing – review & editing a Xia Zhang Investigation a Yihang Jiang Investigation a a Laboratory of Basic Research in Biomass Conversion and Utilization, Department of Thermal Science and Energy Engineering, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, China Laboratory of Basic Research in Biomass Conversion and Utilization, Department of Thermal Science and Energy Engineering University of Science and Technology of China Hefei 230026 China aLaboratory of Basic Research in Biomass Conversion and Utilization, Department of Thermal Science and Energy Engineering, University of Science and Technology of China, Hefei 230026, China b Institute of Energy, Hefei Comprehensive National Science Center, Hefei 230031, China Institute of Energy, Hefei Comprehensive National Science Center Hefei 230031 China bInstitute of Energy, Hefei Comprehensive National Science Center, Hefei 230031, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Lignin, which represents the most abundant renewable aromatic biomass resource on the earth, is promising as an alternative for the production of chemicals. We presented a modified method that provides the hydrogen source in the reaction with a mixed solvent of alcohol, acid and water, replacing the original method that directly provides a hydrogen source with external hydrogen. In addition, a new cobalt supported on nitrogen doped carbon catalyst preparation method (one-pot) was presented. We proposed one-step method in which corn stover lignin is converted to target monomers over Co/AC-N_one-pot catalyst and mixed solvent. The role of the alcohol to acid and water mixed solvent not only extract lignin fragments from the matrix but also provide the hydrogen source. Cobalt which has electronic interaction with the nitrogen reformed alcohols to obtain hydrogen and stabilized lignin intermediates during the reaction by hydrogenation of active bonds. Different kinds of nitrogen including pyridinic and pyrrolic nitrogen functional groups plays a critical role in stabilizing Co. Nearly complete delignification (91%) and high yield of target monomers (23.8%) can be obtained under the conditions (5wt% Co/Ac-N_one-pot, 10:1:1mixture solvent consist of isopropanol/water/ formic acid, 235 °C, 200 min, 0.1 MPa N2), and the selectivity of target monomers was 85%. Circulation experiment of catalyst was performed directly without any operation of the residue, and it could maintain 90% activity in the first four cycles. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lignin Depolymerization Co-based catalysts Hydrogen supply system Aromatic monomers Introduction As the most abundant renewable resource on earth, lignocellulosic biomass is a promising to produce chemicals, fuels, drugs and related materials [1–3]. In order to improve the utilization efficiency of lignocellulose, it is necessary to convert three components, namely: cellulose, hemicellulose, lignin into chemicals or fuels [4–6]. (Hemi) cellulose, which consist of carbohydrate polymers, are relatively stable [7]. Lignin, on the other hand, is biosynthesized in plant cell walls by oxidative radical polymerization of three monolignols (Fig. 1 ) (i.e., p-coumaryl alcohol (H), coniferyl alcohol (G), and sinapyl alcohol (S)) [8]. The fractionation and transformation of these three components are particularly important when fully exploiting the energy potential of lignocellulose [9,10]. Although many methods have been developed to convert carbohydrate components in lignocellulose into useful intermediate chemicals [7,11], the utilization and upgrading of lignin is still in the preliminary stage [12]. However, there is growing recognition that lignin is an attractive renewable aromatic feedstock, and in addition, biorefineries that traditionally focused on the utilization of carbohydrates are cost competitive only when large quantities of lignocellulosic biomass are valorized [13,14]. Therefore, many investigators turned to explore the possibility that lignin is converted to aromatic monomers and exploited [15,16]. So far, an important conclusion from these studies is that lignin obtained after removal of carbohydrates by lignocellulose are very inactive, and one major reason is traditional fractionation methods of lignocellulose alter the chemical structure of its native lignin [17], leading to the breakage of a large proportion of reactive ether linkages and the formation of stable poorly degradable carbon-carbon bonds [18,19]. This explains why the valorization of lignin in the immediate native biomass is higher than that in the post separation. Recently, the selective removal of lignin fragments by hydrogenation and depolymerization of the original lignocellulose, which can be performed under mild conditions, has become a popular biorefinery paradigm [10,20,21]. Ether and ester linkages between hemicellulose and lignin can be cleaved by solvation, and these released reactive lignin intermediates can be stabilized and converted into stable monomers upon hydrogenation involving hydrogen and catalysts [21]. The latter step usually requires catalysts (such as Ru/C [2], Pt/C [22]) with hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) ability, which are mainly used to break the ether bonds existing in lignin, especially the β-O-4 bond (as shown in the Fig. 1, marked red), that is the most common monomers linkage bond of natural lignin, is considered to be the key to depolymerize lignin [2,9]. This process produces highly depolymerized lignin oils, which contain a large number of phenolic monomers [23]. Typically, high initial external hydrogen pressure is proved to be a condition for good yield and selectivity in hydrodeoxygenation [24]. However, for safety reasons, the use of external hydrogen is unfavorable. In addition, hydrogen production is mainly produced from fossil feedstock. In terms of sustainable development, avoiding using external hydrogen and obtaining hydrogen from other sources were necessary [25]. The popular and viable methods now is to provide a hydrogen source via hydrogen transfer during the reaction [26–28]. In the valorization of lignin, Samec et al. using a mixed solution of ethanol and water under the action of a catalyst for the hydrogenolysis of lignin with formic acid and formate as the hydrogen resource, obtaining 37% phenolic yield in a continuous flow system. Similar hydrogen donation strategy has been used in the context of industrial lignin upgrading [20]. Weckhuysen and co-workers reported a two-step approach by first dissolving sulphate, organic solvents and bagasse lignin into a mixed solution of ethanol and water, followed by reforming to produce monomers (17% yield) over the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, with hydrogen being produced in the latter step [8]. Ferrini and Rinaldi et al. proposed a strategy based on isopropanol catalyzed hydrogen transfer, in which isopropanol can be converted to hydrogen acetone and acetone under the action of Raney nickel, and resulting lignin oil yield (25%) was higher than using external hydrogen gas directly [25]. However, since the nickel catalyst readily produces products of aromatic ring saturation during the hydrogenolysis of lignin, careful optimization of the reaction conditions is required and the catalyst is easily deactivated [29,30]. In recent years, more and more attention has been paid to the loading of non-noble metals on nitrogen doped carbon supports as substitutes for noble metals in HDO reactions [2,31]. In particular, some teams have developed heterogeneous cobalt catalysts by loading non noble metal cobalt on nitrogen doped carbon support [32]. These catalysts show high selectivity and activity in the hydrogenation of various benzene compounds (such as nitroaromatics [33,34], methylphenyls [35], etc.) and the catalytic decomposition of formic acid [32]. Based on the exploration on optimization of hydrogen supplying system and selecting of catalyst in lignin hydrogenolysis [7, 25], we presented for the first time using a mixed solution of formic acid and isopropanol and water as the solvent for the hydrodeoxygenation reaction of lignin using cobalt-based catalysts on nitrogen doped carbon supports prepared by a modified catalyst preparation method. Because of the Mott Schottky effect between nitrogen and cobalt, the cobalt surface is electron deficient and easily hydrogenation of lignin to generate stable phenolic monomers. The role of additional cobalt also embodies the reforming of isopropanol to produce hydrogen as hydrogen source for the reaction [36,37]. The use of isopropanol/formic acid/water as the hydrogen-donor solvent has several advantages: the solvation of isopropanol can effectively extract lignin fragments in preparation for the stabilization of active intermediates afterward; the introduction of water increases the rate of hydrogen generation and also accelerates the solvation, favoring the breakage of lignin−carbohydrates complexes (LCCs) [10,38]; the addition of formic acid can not only enhance the hydrogen concentration, but also contributes to the splitting of cellulose and hemicellulose [32], which can be converted to other downstream compounds under the action of catalysts. Herein, we explored the effect of various hydrogen supply systems on the hydrogenation of corn stover lignin, aiming at selecting the best hydrogen supply system. Then, non-noble cobalt metal supported on nitrogen-doped carbon support was used as catalyst and the optimized solution of isopropanol mixed with formic acid and water in 10:1:1 ratio was used as hydrogen supply system to explore the relationship between monomers yield, reaction time and temperature. This study provided an effective way for the hydrogenolysis of lignin and the utilization of the three components of corn stover. Experimental section Materials 5wt% Ru/C, Al2O3 was purchased from Aladdin, formic acid (99.9%), ethanol (99.9%), sulfuric acid (99.9%), methanol (99.9%), isopropanol (99.9%), acetone (99.9%), Ni(NO3)2•6H2O (99%), Cu(NO3)2•6H2O(99%),Co(NO3)2•6H2O (99%), NaBH4, activated carbon were purchased from Sinopharm. MCM-41was purchased from XFNAN. Corn stover comes from Mengcheng County in Northwest Anhui Province, China. After harvesting, the stover is air-dried naturally. The whole stover is first cut into small fragments by a common mill, and then washed with deionized water to remove surface dust and non-stover impurities. The cleaned stover was dried in a 60 °C oven and further ground by a laboratory-scale high-speed crusher, and stored through a 30–100mesh sieve. Then the treated stover was extracted in a solution of 1:1 mixture of toluene and ethanol (solid-liquid ratio of 1:10) in an oil bath at 95 °C for 12 h to remove the oil and washed 2,3 times with ethanol. Before the experiment, the solid powder was dried at 105 °C overnight and stored in a glass desiccator. General catalytic reaction Typically, 1.0 g corn stover and 0.1 g catalyst were added to 30 ml solution. After the reactor was sealed, 10 bar of N2 was replaced three times to ensure that the system was N2 atmosphere, and finally the N2 pressure was reduced to 1 bar. The reactors were stirred at 700 rpm using magnetic stirring. The reaction time and temperature depend on the specific situation. After the reaction is completed, the whole reactor is put into water and rapidly cooled to room temperature. The product is filtered with a sand core funnel to separate solid residues (including catalysts). The remaining liquid product was evaporated at 40 °C to remove the solvent and obtain crude lignin oil (containing lignin oil and sugar and their derivatives), which was dissolved in a mixed solvent consisting of 100 ml of water and10 ml of DCM, and sonicated for 10 min. After simple separation, the obtained DCM organic solvent phase (analyzed by GC, GC-MS, 2D HSQC) and the aqueous phase solution were used for subsequent product analysis (analyzed by HPLC). Commercial granular activated carbon is grounded and sieved into 15–20 mesh particles for use Synthesis of Phenanthroline sulfuric acid salt (L1-H 2 SO 4 ):5.0g of 1,10-phenanthroline monohydrate (L1, 25 mmol) was dissolved in 25 ml ethanol under magnetic stirring. Then the 5g 98% H2SO4 (50mmol) diluted with 25ml deionized water was added. The mixture solution was stirring for 6 h. Finally, phenanthroline sulfuric acid salt (L1-H2SO4) was obtained after the mixture was evaporated to remove methanol and dried overnight at 423K. Synthesis of nitrogen-doped carbon (AC-N): 0.5gL1-H2SO4 and 1.0g AC were dispersed in the mixture solvent consisting of 10ml deionized water and 13ml ethanol. The mixture was stirring for 12 h. After filtration of all solvents by sand core funnel, the black solid was dried in vacuum for 5 h at 343K, followed by calcination at 700 °C under nitrogen atmosphere for 4 h, and the heating rate is 5 °C min−1. Finally, the nitrogen-doped carbon was obtained. Synthesis of catalyst_wet: Typically, in the case of 5wt % Co/AC-N_wet, 0.125g Co(NO3)2•6H2O was dissolved in the mixture solvent consisting of 6ml deionized water and 10ml ethanol. Then 0.5g nitrogen-doped carbon was added. After stirring for 3 h, 0.041g NaBH4 solution dissolving in 6ml deionized water was added in 0 °C water bath slowly. The obtained mixture was stirring for another 6 h. After that, the mixture was filtered by sand core funnel and the obtained solid was washed using deionized water to remove the Na+. The solid was dried in vacuum for 5 h at 343K, followed by calcination at 700 °C under nitrogen atmosphere for 4 h, and the heating rate is 5 °C min−1. Finally, the 5wt% Co/AC-N_wet was obtained. Changing the N functionalized carbon to activated carbon,MCM-41,Al2O3, Co/AC,Co/MCM-41,Co/Al2O3 were obtained, respectively. Synthesis of catalyst_one-pot: Typically, in the case of 5wt % Co/AC-N_one-pot, 0.125g Co(NO3)2•6H2O was dissolved in the mixture solvent consisting of 6ml deionized water and 10ml ethanol, and a clear light orange solution was obtained. Then 0.23g L1-H2SO4 was added, and the solution change to dark orange, following 0.4g activated carbon was added. After the mixture stirring for 6 h, 0.041g NaBH4 solution dissolving in 6ml deionized water was added in 0 °C water bath slowly. The obtained mixture was stirring for another 6 h. After that, the mixture was filtered by sand core funnel and the obtained solid was washed using deionized water to remove the Na+. The solid was dried in vacuum for 5 h at 343K, followed by calcination at 700 °C under nitrogen atmosphere for 4 h, and the heating rate is 5 °C min−1. Finally, the 5wt% Co/AC-N_one-pot was obtained. Change the dosage of Co(NO3)2•6H2O, 2.5wt%Co/AC-N_one-pot,7wt%Co/AC-N_one-pot,10wt%Co/AC-N_one-pot,15wt%Co/AC-N_one-pot were obtained, respectively. And replacing Co(NO3)2•6H2O to the Ni(NO3)2•6H2O, Ni/AC-N_one-pot obtained. Adjusting the content and proportion of Cu(NO3)2•6H2O, Ni(NO3)2•6H2O and Co(NO3)2•6H2O, the different ratio of Co-Ni(-Cu)/AC-N_one-pot were obtained. Result and discussion Catalyst characterization It can be seen from XRD (Fig. 2 a) that Co/AC-N and nitrogen-free Co/AC exhibited similar patterns with diffraction peaks located at about 24.7° and 43.7°, corresponding to the (002) and (100) planes of graphitic carbon network, and the intensity of the (002) peak broadens with the doping of nitrogen [39]. In the case of the (100) peak corresponding to the interlayer organization of carbon, the introduction of nitrogen causes the intensity peak to disappear. Since all samples were synthesized at the same calcination temperature of 700 °C, the above changes in the XRD pattern clearly indicate that doping nitrogen into the carbon skeleton can make it more disordered [33]. The catalysts labeled wet and one-pot are prepared in different order of cobalt source. The former is loaded with Co by wet impregnation after the carrier has synthesized, and the latter is added with cobalt source during the carrier is synthesizing. XRD diagram also shows that the catalyst prepared by wet method has obvious Co peak. However, no visible diffraction of Co was detected in the one-pot catalyst, probably due to cobalt metal are distributed in a small size version. The TEM results (Fig. 2e,f) are in good agreement with the XRD diagram that cobalt metal is well dispersed in one-pot catalyst and has agglomeration in wet catalyst. In addition, we did NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) for both catalysts (Fig. 3 b), which showed that desorption peak located at 680 °C, corresponding to strong acid sites. Although acidic sites do not represent active sites, extended studies have been reported that acid sites have a significant effect on the structure of C-O bonds [12,21] The result revealed that the NH3 desorption of the Co/AC-N_one-pot catalyst was higher than that of the Co/AC-N_wet catalyst, which indicates that Co/AC-N_one-pot catalyst has more acidic sites than that of Co/AC-N_wet catalyst. In order to improve the utilization rate of active metals in catalysts, it is necessary to explore the most appropriate loading amount of active metals, and the corresponding XRD diagram is in Fig. 2b. Obviously, when the load increase to 10wt%, the corresponding peak strength of cobalt metal begins to increase, and the BET diagram showed that the specific surface area and pore volume of the catalyst decrease with the introduction of nitrogen and continuously metal loading increasing (Fig. 2c,d and Table 1 ). It indicates that the doping of nitrogen destroys the original regular structure of the carbon skeleton and the increasing of loading leading to agglomeration. Fig. 2a also showed that the 5wt% Co/AC catalyst without nitrogen doping is well dispersed and has no obvious metal cobalt peak, but its activity is much lower than that of the catalyst after nitrogen doping (Table 2 ). This observation indicates that the catalytic activity of Co particles on the Co/AC-N catalysts is more affected by the doping of N as compared to the catalytic activity of Co/AC. In order to explore the effect of nitrogen doping in detail, Co XPS was performed. The characteristic spectrum of the 5wt%Co/AC-N catalyst contains the characteristic peak of Co, O, N, and C (Fig. 3a). As a contrast, the spectrum of the 5wt%Co/AC, which without N dropped, do not contain the characteristic peak of N. In the Co2p spectrum (Fig. 3c), Co2p1/2(797.76eV) and Co2p3/2(781.76eV) are accompanied by their respective satellite peaks (Co2p1/2 sat. and Co2p3/2 sat.) [35]. And the presence of Co2+ compounds can also be demonstrated from the binding energy difference of 16.0 eV [37]. Particularly, the binding energy value of Co2+ in Co/AC-N_wet and Co/AC-N_one-pot (Fig. 3ci,ii) were higher (0.4 and 0.5eV) than the Co/AC (Fig. 3ciii), implying there exist the electron transfer between Co2+ and nitrogen-doped support. However, the binding energy value of Co2+ of wet catalyst is only 0.1 eV deviation from one-pot catalyst, the activity of the two catalysts in the reaction is different, presumably the difference caused by the different chemical states of N. N1s XPS indicates that there exist four kinds of nitrogen species on the surface of the Co/AC-N catalysts, including pyrrolic N, graphitic N, pyridinic N and chemisorbed N-oxide [39] (Fig. 3d), which are distinguished by binding energy. In particular, pyrrolic and pyridinic nitrogen sites are the main species in the carbon skeleton, with binding energy of 400.7 and 398.9eV [31]. The XPS peak appearing at 402.3 and 404.8eV is assigned to the graphitic and chemisorbed N-oxide [32]. As can be seen, wet catalyst (Fig. 3d iii) contains a small amount of chemisorbed N-oxide, while one-pot catalyst does not. Correspondingly, the latter contains a small amount of graphitic N, while the former does not. Because the nitrogen content of these varieties is relatively small compared with the total nitrogen content, the presence of these two kinds of nitrogen should not be the main reason for the change of catalyst activity. The more obvious phenomenon in N1s XPS spectrum is that pyridinic N content in one-pot catalyst (Fig. 3di,ii) is obviously greater than that in wet. And pyridinic nitrogen site was the main species embedded in the carbon skeleton, which can affect the site electron density of the absorbed Co species significantly. Therefore, the reason for the great difference in activity between the wet and one-pot catalysts is likely to lie in that pyridinic N has a great influence on the reactivity in nitrogen doping. Optimization of the solvent system The series of experiments were carried out using dry corn stover (1.0g) as raw material, solvent (30ml) and 5wt% commercial Ru/C (0.1g) as catalyst at 210 °C for 200 min with 700 rpm stirring speed and 0.1 MPa N2 pressure. In the process of catalytic conversion of corn stover lignocellulose, the depolymerization of lignin to produce monomers is critical hydrogenation step. Therefore, the evaluation of the effect of the hydrogen supply system is based on the total amount of monomers produced by the fractionation–hydrogenolysis process of corn stover (Scheme 1 ). As can be seen from Fig. 4 , with the increase of water ratio (columns 1–6), the monomers yield showed a trend of first increasing and then decreasing, especially when the ratio was less than 1:1, the yield decreased sharply. When the solvent was all water, the monomers yield was less than 3%. One possible reason is that very few products of lignin depolymerization can be dissolved in water. When the proportion of water rises, the contact between active intermediates and catalysts is prevented, the yield will decrease. However, from the point of view of product distribution, the proportion of various products changed slightly, which also reflected that the low yield was due to the difference of hydrogen supply system under different ratios of isopropanol and water. Interestingly, when the ratio of isopropanol to water is 5:1, the yield is the highest and the effect of hydrogen supply is the best, which indicates that isopropanol and water have a certain synergistic effect under the appropriate ratio, but not a single system of isopropanol or water has a good effect of hydrogen supply. This provides a reference for improving the existing hydrogen supply system. Although many literatures have pointed out that the hydrogen supply capacity of isopropanol is excellent among alcohols, it still needs catalyst and harsh environment to realize its reformation to hydrogen [27]. Formic acid, as a well-known reagent that can decompose to generate hydrogen under mild conditions, is widely used in hydrogen supply systems [26,40]. Our research group explored the synergistic effect between formic acid and different optimized hydrogen supply systems. Similarly, when the ratio of alcohol to formic acid to water is 10:1:1, isopropanol exhibits better hydrogen supply effect than ethanol (Fig. 4, columns 9 and 10, monomers yield, 15.39% vs 12.57%). The same phenomenon also occurs when the ratio of alcohol to acid is 5:1, the yield obtained by using isopropanol is 14.18%, while ethanol is 11.74% (Fig. 4, columns 7 and 8). These data also confirmed the good hydrogen supply ability of isopropanol in alcoholic reagents. Compared with the system of isopropanol with water ratio of 5:1 and pure isopropanol, the system of adding formic acid has a significantly higher total yield of monomers and a much better effect of hydrogen supply. Moreover, Ferulic acid (Fig. 4, marked 7) in the product disappeared after the addition of formic acid, which corresponded to the increase of 4-ethyl-guaiacol (Fig. 4, marked 2), implying that the hydrodeoxygenation capacity of the system was improved. In addition, the conversion of hyperoxic monomers such as Ferulic acid can also greatly increase the calorific value of the product, which is of great significance for the subsequent upgrading of corn stover lignin to liquid fuel. Column 11 in Fig. 4 is a hydrogenation and deoxygenation system often used by many teams with external hydrogen sources [41]. Compared with the optimized hydrogen supply system with the ratio of isopropanol to formic acid and water of 10:1:1, the latter has better hydrogen supply effect and higher monomers yield. More detailed tests for optimizing mixed solvents are presented in Figs. S1–S4, and the reaction conditions is the same as the Fig. 4. This finding provides a new system choice for subsequent reactions requiring hydrogenation. Therefore, in the later experiments, the hydrogen supply system used a mixed solution of isopropanol and formic acid and water at a ratio of 10:1:1. Catalytic conversion of corn stover lignin In order to verify that catalyst has good hydrodeoxygenation for lignin depolymerization of corn stover, the blank control experiment (Table 2 entry 1) was conducted under the conditions of 235 °C and 200 min, and the solvent system was the optimized hydrogen supply one (the ratio of isopropanol to formic acid and water was 10:1:1). The total yield of monomer obtained was only 7.67% (compared with 23.81%, 5wt% Co/AC-N_one-pot Table 1 entry6), but the delignification was as high as 85%, while the pulp retention rate was only 8%. One possible reason is that with the introduction of formic acid and water into the solvent system, the degree of hydrolysis of cellulose and hemicellulose is greatly enhanced and lignin is more easily exposed for hydrogenation reaction. Next, we studied the effect of nitrogen doping on the catalytic activity, with 5wt% Co supported on pure activated carbon as catalyst (Table 2 entry2 vs entry6). Under the same other conditions, the yield of monomers obtained is only 10.70%, which is much lower than that of the nitrogen-doped catalyst by 23.81%. The results show that the doping of nitrogen greatly affects the catalytic activity. The carbohydrate section and the total mass balance were explored under the optimum conditions. With the action of catalyst and solvation, cellulose and hemicellulose are mainly decomposed into C5 and C6 sugars, which are converted into furfural compounds (Table S3 Fig. S8 Table S5). The total yield of residue, DCM phase and water phase products derived from the corn stover carbohydrate part was 91.4wt%, accounting for the sum of glucans and xylans (Table S4). In consideration of the process does not require any special treatment which aims at carbohydrate, the obtained yields of carbohydrate-derived products are passable. Table 2 entry3,4 represents the effect of different supports on the catalytic reaction activity. MCM-41, as a pure silica zeolite, is a carrier of organized and has no acidity. As a comparison, γ-Al2O3 is a carrier of amorphous and has Lewis acidity. The yield of monomers obtained by the reaction of the two catalyst supports is almost the same and extremely low (8.68 % vs 9.00%). The XRD pattern (Fig. S5) shows that the metal cobalt on the two supports is well dispersed, so excluding that the poor activity is caused by the aggregation of active sites, one possible reason is that there is no electronic interaction between cobalt and the support, the same as pure activated carbon as support (Table 2 entry2). In addition, the results showed that acidity and amorphous state of the catalyst support had no prominent effect on the hydrogenolysis of corn stover lignin. In addition, the effect of different preparation methods of catalysts on the activity was also studied (Table 2 entry5,6). As can be seen, the catalytic activity of the catalyst which made by one-pot method is higher (monomers yield: 17.09% vs 23.81%). Automatically, excessive metal load will greatly reduce the active sites of the active metal cobalt, thereby the reactivity of the catalyst declining [35]. The yield of monomers obtained from catalysts with different loadings also verified this fact (Table 2 entry6–8 Table S1). In the field of biomass energy, nickel has many applications in catalytic depolymerization of lignocellulose as an active metal [1,30]. The effect of nickel on the catalytic conversion of corn stover lignin (Table 2 entry 9,10) was also studied. The yield of monomer was 21.05%, but the selectivity to target product was very low (Fig. S6), only 60.8%. Compared with 5wt%Co/AC-N_one-pot, the selectivity of target product was 84.5%. In many cases, the electron transfer between a tandem of active metals can significantly improve the catalytic activity and have a strong synergistic effect [42]. In particular, this effect between cobalt and nickel has been widely used in the field of biomass electrochemistry [29,43]. It should be noted that the catalytic activity of Co and Ni bimetallic supported on N-doped carbon support is lower than that of single metal (Table 2 entry 9 vs10), and the same effect can be observed by changing the bimetallic loading ratio (Table S2). XRD patterns show that when Co and Ni are loaded together, each metal has a very high peak and agglomeration phenomenon is greatly increased (Fig. S7). This is also the main reason for the decrease of catalytic activity. In addition, the influence of copper as an active metal on the overall activity of the catalyst (Table 2 entry 11–13) was also explored. Similarly, when copper and cobalt or copper and nickel are jointly supported, their catalytic activity is lower than that of cobalt and nickel alone. Interestingly, the activity is higher than that of any two active metals, when cobalt, copper and nickel are jointly loaded. The activities exhibited by different catalysts in the reaction may differ as well as the ability of the catalysts to catalyze in situ the production of hydrogen from mixed solvents. Experimental results show that different catalysts differ in their ability to generate hydrogen gas in situ with mixed solvents. The reaction system, in the absence of catalyst or in the presence of catalyst with poor activity, would indeed be a little more pressure than that of the catalyst with good effect. But this difference is not obvious and should be insufficient as a measure of the activity of the catalyst in the reaction. Phenolic monomers from corn stover The liquid products obtained from the reaction were extracted with DCM and water before lignin oil analysis. The obtained DCM lignin oil, which had removed soluble sugars, was used for subsequent chemical analysis. Qualitative and quantitative analysis of lignin monomers was carried out using GC-MS and GC by comparison with authentic samples. By comparing the presence and absence of catalysts in GC (Fig. 5 g), the yield of target monomers in the product under the action of 5wt% Co/AC-N catalyst exceeded 80% of the total monomer yield, while the yield of monomers without catalyst was very low and almost no selectivity was obtained. In order to reflect the comparison of molecular weight, we made the Gel Permeation Chromatography of DCM oil (Fig. 5h). Signal at 220Mw was consistent with monomers and signal at 550, 800, 1000Mw correspond to dimer, trimer and tetramer molecular weights. This Gel Permeation Chromatography suggests a successful depolymerization of corn stover lignin over the Co/Ac-N_one-pot catalyst. In order to verify the chemical structure of the monomer, the liquid products obtained from the reaction were analyzed by GC-MS, and the product distribution and the chemical structure of the corresponding peaks were shown in Fig. S8. A 2D HSQC NMR spectrum of the DCM lignin oil generated from the 5wt%Co/AC-N, 2.5wt%Co/AC-N and blank catalyzed reaction is shown in Fig. 5a,c and e. C-H correlation signals of monomers were marked according to the comparison with standard NMR spectra. The intensity of cross signals of lignin linkages, including β-aryl ether (β-O-4, A), phenylcoumaran (β-5, B), resinol (β-β, C) [9], was high in blank experiment. After the addition of catalyst, the signal intensity of ether bond was obviously decreased, indicating that the depolymerization of lignin increased under the action of catalyst. Parameter investigation As is shown in Fig. 6 , with the increase of temperature, the yield of monomers and delignification are increasing. At 210 °C, the delignification reached 85%, at which the yield of monomers was 18.86%, and when the temperature continued to rise to 235 °C, the delignification and the yield of monomers reached the highest, 91% and 23.8%, respectively. The same phenomenon occurred in the first 200 min of reaction time, and the yield of monomers increased rapidly, reaching the highest level at 200 min. After prolonging the reaction time, the monomers yield decreased slightly, 22.14% and 21.01% at 400 min and 600 min, respectively. This may be due to the prolongation of the reaction time leading the condensation of active intermediates, resulting in a decrease in the yield. In addition, the distribution of the products is also related to temperature. At 260 °C, not only the overall yield decreased, but also the proportion of others in the target product became significantly larger, which is attributed to the enhanced condensation degree of the active intermediate produced by the lignin depolymerization of corn stover with the increase of temperature, resulting in a decrease in the yield of monomers. In addition, the increase of temperature makes it difficult to predict the breakage of the branched chain on the benzene ring, and the formation of unknown phenols is significantly increased. Regeneration of catalyst In this work, cellulose and hemicellulose are almost degraded, and lignin is hydrogenated and deoxygenated to produce corresponding monomers and other substances, the remaining solid residue (except catalyst) of the reaction is only 11%, most of which are ash. Without any treatment, solids (residues and catalysts) obtained after the reaction are directly put into the next set of experiments as catalyst for the reaction. The results of the five cycles are shown in the Fig. 7 . The catalyst could maintain a high yield of active for monomers over 90% in the first four cycles compared with the fresh catalyst, which may be attributed to the strong electron attraction between cobalt nanoparticles and nitrogen-doped carbon carriers. However, the reduction in the monomers yield of the fifth cycle was obvious, probably due to the slight agglomeration in the spent catalyst (Fig. S9) and there was too much ash and moisture accumulated in the system, which hindered the contact between the catalyst and the substrate, thus reducing the catalytic effect. Conclusion This paper showed that the optimized solvent with the ratio of isopropanol to formic acid and water at 10:1:1 was used as the hydrogen supply system, and the Co/AC-N_one-pot synthesized by the improved preparation method was used as the catalyst to depolymerize the lignin of corn stover with nearly complete delignification (91%) and high yield of target monomers (23.8%). The (hemi) cellulose section is also used efficiently, and a considerable part is converted into compounds such as glucose and furfural alcohol, which realizes the effective utilization of the three components of lignocellulose. In addition, the electronic interaction between cobalt and nitrogen-doped carbon support makes the catalyst exhibit good stability and can still maintain more than 90% activity in the first four cycles of experiments. This work provides an economically pathway for corn stover lignin valorization as well as fractionation and utilization of all of the herbaceous biomass. coredata.dc:description: Lignin, which represents the most abundant renewable aromatic biomass resource on the earth, is promising as an alternative for the production of chemicals. We presented a modified method that provides the hydrogen source in the reaction with a mixed solvent of alcohol, acid and water, replacing the original method that directly provides a hydrogen source with external hydrogen. In addition, a new cobalt supported on nitrogen doped carbon catalyst preparation method (one-pot) was presented. We proposed one-step method in which corn stover lignin is converted to target monomers over Co/AC-N_one-pot catalyst and mixed solvent. The role of the alcohol to acid and water mixed solvent not only extract lignin fragments from the matrix but also provide the hydrogen source. Cobalt which has electronic interaction with the nitrogen reformed alcohols to obtain hydrogen and stabilized lignin intermediates during the reaction by hydrogenation of active bonds. Different kinds of nitrogen including pyridinic and pyrrolic nitrogen functional groups plays a critical role in stabilizing Co. Nearly complete delignification (91%) and high yield of target monomers (23.8%) can be obtained under the conditions (5wt% Co/Ac-N_one-pot, 10:1:1mixture solvent consist of isopropanol/water/ formic acid, 235 °C, 200 min, 0.1 MPa N2), and the selectivity of target monomers was 85%. Circulation experiment of catalyst was performed directly without any operation of the residue, and it could maintain 90% activity in the first four cycles.
coredata.dc:title: Valorization of lignin in native corn stover via fractionation-hydrogenolysis process over cobalt-supported catalyst without external hydrogen
